required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ecological Momentary Determinants of Sedentary Behavior
clinical_study.official_title: TranSITion: Ecological Momentary Determinants of Sedentary Behavior

brief_summary.textblock: A two phase trial to understand the personal, behavioral, environmental, and contextual factors that underpin sedentary behavior and to systematically test a series of contextual prompt characteristics that may lead to subsequent change in sedentary behavior.

detailed_description.textblock:
Phase 1: This is an observational study that will utilized Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA), to determine which personal (e.g. fatigue, mood, and stress level), behavioral (e.g. watching TV, working at desk, and eating meals), environmental (e.g. being at home or work, time of the day, and weather) and contextual factors were associated with sedentary behavior. Three EMAs per day will be sent randomly sent to participants on weekdays (Monday to Friday), for four consecutive weeks (total of 20 days). During these days, participants will also wear an activPAL device to objectively measure sedentary behavior. We will identify the combination of factors most likely to precede and proceed short (<30 min) and long (â‰¥30 min) bouts of sedentary behavior.
Phase 2: Using a micro-randomized trial, we will test whether an email based prompt is more likely to elicit a proximal effect (e.g., a postural response defined as a transition from seated to standing or seated to moving within 5 minutes to interrupt prolonged sitting) than no prompt. A secondary aim of this study is to determine whether prompts that encourage standing are more likely to elicit a response than those that encourage moving. An exploratory aim is to examine whether varying the content of the stand or move prompt to include combinations of short term goals and employer approval, influence the magnitude of response.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: PART B: A three-factor design with two-levels yielded eight experimental conditions, half of which encouraged standing more (stand; n prompt types = 80, n total prompts =800) and the other half encouraged moving more (move; n prompt types = 80, n total prompts =800).

primary_outcome.description: Objectively measured minutes of sitting, standardized to an 8h workday.
Objectively measured minutes of standing, standardized to an 8h workday.

primary_outcome.measure: Minutes of light-intensity physical activity (minutes/8h workday)
primary_outcome.description: Objectively measured minutes of light-intensity physical activity, standardized to an 8h workday.

primary_outcome.measure: Minutes of moderate-vigorous physical activity (minutes/8h workday)
primary_outcome.description: Objectively measured minutes of moderate-vigorous physical activity, standardized to an 8h workday.

secondary_outcome.description: Affective states will be assessed using an EMA survey based on the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule questionnaire. An open-source app (Personal Analytic Companion App) will be used to deliver EMA questions randomly throughout a participant's workday. This will allow us to measure self-reported levels of positive or negative affect.

arm_group.description: An email based prompt was sent- containing either a stand or move message. Exploratory variations of the prompt were designed to include the addition of a goal e.g., stand for the next 5-minutes, and/or employer support e.g., PTS says "stand for the next 5 minutes".

Prompt delivery was sequentially randomized to be sent (ST) or not sent (NST) to all participants (probability of 0.5), at eight decision points per day (between 9am and 5pm), to achieve a total of 3200 randomizations across participants (160 per participant). Therefore 50% of the time, no prompt was sent.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Full-time employees
- Males or females
- Ages 18-65
- Sedentary working habits (as indicated by >7 hrs/day of sedentary time at work in the Sedentary Behavior Questionnaire)
- Willing to engage in the study assessment and intervention for 10 weeks.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-ambulatory, pregnant
- Non-English speaking
- Diagnosis of psychiatric problems or taking psychiatric medications
- Medical history that prohibits prolonged standing.
